item.title: Spain Election: Divided Nation Holds 3rd National Vote Since 2015
item.media:description: From left: The far-left Podemos party leader Pablo Iglesias, the conservative Popular Party leader Pablo Casado, the center-right Ciudadanos leader Albert Rivera and Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of the Socialist party at a televised debate in Madrid on Tuesday.
item.description: The issue of Catalan independence, and the rise of the far-right Vox party, are important elements in the vote on Sunday. The only certainty seems to be more party fragmentation.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Two Super-Rich Families Ended Up on Opposite Sides of Easter Attacks
item.media:description: Investigators at the Shangri-La Hotel in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Easter Sunday.
item.description: In an instant, five of their children were blown to pieces in the Sri Lanka bombings, one family slaughtered by the other.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, KAI SCHULTZ, MUJIB MASHAL and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: South Korea Dispatch: Running Out of Children, a South Korea School Enrolls Illiterate Grandmothers
item.media:description: Hwang Wol-geum, 70, left corner, attending a school trip in South Korea with other grandmothers and her grandchildren.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: As the birthrate plummets in South Korea, rural schools are emptying. To fill its classrooms, one school opened its doors to women who have for decades dreamed of learning to read.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and CHANG W. LEE

item.title: Raid on House Linked to Sri Lanka Easter Bombings Leaves 15 Dead
item.media:description: Security personnel on Saturday guarded the site of an overnight gun battle between Sri Lankan troops and suspected Islamist militants on the east coast.
item.description: The wife and child of the suspected mastermind of the suicide attacks were seriously wounded when the raid turned violent. ISIS said its fighters were among those killed.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and HANNAH BEECH

item.title: Britain’s Big Squeeze: Austerity-Battered U.K. ‘Retreating Behind a Nuclear Shield’
item.media:description: A child climbed on a tank with the British Army in Narva, in eastern Estonia near the Russian border. The defense minister praised the British presence as a symbol of solidarity.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: As Britain spends heavily on big-ticket items like nuclear-armed submarines, its military is no longer deemed capable of defending the homeland by itself.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Errors Raise Questions About Sri Lankan Response to Bombing
item.media:description: The devastation at St. Sebastian’s Church. The Sri Lankan government had ignored repeated warnings of attacks.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A series of failures in preventing and investigating the Easter bombing has exposed rifts in the government and brought accusations of incompetence.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL, DHARISHA BASTIANS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Amid U.S. Silence, Gulf Nations Back the Military in Sudan’s Revolution
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Sudan greeting soldiers in Khartoum, the capital. Many protest leaders are pressing for civilian rule, while Saudi Arabia has backed the military.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: As protesters and generals argue over who should run Sudan, the United States has been unusually quiet. Saudi Arabia and its allies are filling the vacuum.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Belarus Building Site Yields the Bones of 1,214 Holocaust Victims
item.media:description: Tatyana Lakhay looking over the building site in the center of Brest, Belarus, where the remains of 1,214 people were found.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Activists, who say the city knew about the mass grave for slaughtered Jews, ask why a permit was issued.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Spanish Election May Pivot on an Aging and Depleted Heartland
item.media:description: San Esteban de Gormaz, in Soria, now the least populated province of Spain — with 88,000 inhabitants.
item.media:credit: Nacho Hernandez for The New York Times
item.description: Even as Spain’s interior provinces empty out, they punch above their weight politically and could determine the outcome of Sunday’s national election.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Serial-Killing Case Shocks Cyprus as Police Come In for Criticism
item.media:description: A vigil for the victims of a suspected serial killer in front of the presidential palace in Nicosia, Cyprus, on Friday.
item.description: The police were searching for more victims after a military officer confessed to seven killings, apparently targeting female immigrants and their children.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Knives Were Left on Japanese Prince’s School Desk, Police Say
item.media:description: Prince Hisahito with his parents, Prince Akishino, left, and Princess Kiko, at Ochanomizu University Junior High School in Tokyo, which he entered this month.
item.description: The Tokyo police were investigating security footage indicating that an adult had trespassed on the grounds of the school attended by Prince Hisahito, 12.
item.dc:creator: MAKIKO INOUE and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Hashim Aslami Has Just One Word for Afghan Farmers: Saffron
item.media:description: Hashim Aslami and his wife, Talat Aslami, at their apartment in Kabul, Afghanistan. “Except when I am asleep, the rest of the time is all on saffron,” Mr. Aslami said.
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.description: For two decades, he preached the virtues of the spice as an alternative to traditional crops and opium poppies. Today, it is a rare success story for his country.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Journalist’s Death Jolts Northern Ireland Politicians Back to Negotiating Table
item.media:description: The Republic of Ireland’s foreign minister, Simon Coveney, and Britain’s secretary of state for Northern Ireland, Karen Bradley, announced that they had convened talks for May.
item.description: The main political parties in Northern Ireland have agreed to restart negotiations to revive the province’s dormant regional parliament.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Polish Teachers End Strike to Allow Exams but Tell Government It’s Not Over
item.media:description: A teachers’ strike in Poland drew thousands of people to the streets of Warsaw this month.
item.description: A three-week work stoppage forced thousands of schools to close, posing a challenge for the governing party ahead of national elections.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Brazil’s Judiciary, Once Symbol of Anti-Corruption Drive, Now Faces Scrutiny
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting some of the Brazilian Supreme Court’s recent decisions hold a coffin painted with the court’s initials.
item.description: Decisions by top justices have begun to turn the population against them after years in which the judiciary had grown in the population’s esteem as the face of an anti-corruption drive.
item.dc:creator: LETÍCIA CASADO and MANUELA ANDREONI

item.title: For U.S. Commandos in the Philippines, a Water Pump Is a New Weapon Against ISIS
item.media:description: It has taken two months, an American Special Operations civil affairs team, three nonprofit organizations and a platoon from the Philippine Army to bring a water pump to Padas, in the southern Philippines.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: A water pump is linked to the defeat of the Islamic State’s self-proclaimed caliphate in Iraq and Syria and the Pentagon’s race to stop the group’s resurgence in other parts of the globe.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Canada Letter: Are Middle-Class Canadians Still the World’s Richest?
item.media:description: A minivan plant in Windsor, Ontario, where 1,500 jobs will be cut this fall.
item.description: Five years ago, an analysis by The Times found that middle-class Canadians had surpassed their American counterparts. But class is as much a state of mind as it is about numbers.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russia, Joe Biden, Avengers: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: A Trans Woman Got 3 Minutes to Speak in Armenia’s Parliament. Threats Followed.
item.media:description: Lilit Martirosyan at the National Assembly of Armenia in Yerevan. She has received dozens of death threats since speaking there.
item.description: Lilit Martirosyan was the first transgender woman to speak in Armenia’s National Assembly, according to organizers. The backlash began immediately.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: After Duterte’s Threats Over Tons of Old Trash, Canada Says It’s Working on It
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has threatened “war” against Canada over a long-simmering trash dispute.
item.description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines said he was ready to “declare war” with Canada over hundreds of tons of waste shipped to his country over five years ago.
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS

item.title: Want a Break in the 3-Hour ‘Avengers’ Movie? You’ll Need a Passport or a Time Machine
item.media:description: Moviegoers at Williamsburg Cinemas in Brooklyn awaiting the start of “Avengers: Endgame” on Thursday. Many would not get up for more than three hours.
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
item.description: Some theaters overseas are providing an intermission for the blockbuster “Avengers: Endgame,” but American moviegoers who want to step away must strategize.
item.dc:creator: JULIA JACOBS

item.title: ‘There’s Poison in the Sea’: An Oil Spill Fouls a Tropical Eden
item.media:description: The Hong Kong-flagged Solomon Trader, carrying bauxite mined on Rennell Island, ran aground in violent weather in February and has been leaking oil ever since.
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.description: On Rennell, an impoverished Pacific island, mining had already scarred the land. Now an oil spill has polluted the water and threatens a World Heritage site.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Global Health: Religious Objections to the Measles Vaccine? Get the Shots, Faith Leaders Say
item.media:description: A demonstrator in Rockland County, N.Y., after officials banned unvaccinated children from public spaces. The Anti-Defamation League has strongly objected to the appropriation of Holocaust symbols by vaccine critics.
item.description: Devout parents who are worried about vaccines often object to ingredients from pigs or fetuses. But the leaders of major faiths have examined these fears and still vigorously endorse vaccination.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: American Student Misidentified as Sri Lanka Suspect Faces Backlash
item.media:description: Amara Majeed, a student at Brown University and a prominent Muslim activist in the United States, heard from relatives in Sri Lanka that her photo was mistakenly included in a Sri Lankan police alert.
item.media:credit: Barbara Haddock Taylor/The Baltimore Sun, via Associated Press
item.description: Sri Lankan authorities mistakenly posted Amara Majeed’s image alongside a list of suspects wanted in connection with the Easter attacks.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Times Insider: In a Secret Bunker in the Andes, a Wall That Was Really a Window
item.description: Before a video interview with an Ecuadorean intelligence chief, I thought I was adjusting a dimmer switch. What I inadvertently revealed broke our story open.
item.dc:creator: JONAH M. KESSEL

item.title: Cyclone Kenneth Lashes Mozambique, With Floods Feared
item.media:description: The battered coast at Wimbi Beach in Pemba.
item.media:credit: Nour Hemici/World Food Programme, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A day after making landfall in Mozambique, which is still recovering from the effects of Cyclone Idai, Cyclone Kenneth destroyed homes and killed at least one person.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and KIMON de GREEF

item.title: Joe Biden, N.F.L. Draft, ‘Avengers: Endgame’: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Soldiers outside a mosque in Kattankudy, Sri Lanka, on Thursday. The preacher accused of masterminding Sunday’s attacks used to live in the city.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Durable, Adaptable Cork
item.media:description: The entire exterior of the Korkenzieher Haus, or Corkscrew House, is made of cork. “The client wanted to be different,” said Andreas Reeg of Rundzwei, the architectural firm that designed the residence.
item.description: Architects and designers are discovering the many benefits of building with cork, a material long associated with the wine industry.
item.dc:creator: JOANN PLOCKOVA

item.title: Sri Lanka’s President Vows a Search of Every Home, as New Violence Erupts
item.media:description: Soldiers guarding a mosque in Kattankudy, Sri Lanka, on Thursday. Zaharan Hashim, a radical Muslim preacher accused of masterminding the Easter Sunday attacks, used to live in the city.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Explosions and shootings continued to shake the country, as President Maithripala Sirisena tried to deflect anger at the government’s failure to stop the Easter Sunday bombings.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: After the Sri Lanka Terror Attacks, Muslims Fear Backlash
item.description: As Sri Lanka mourns around 250 people killed in a series of terrorist attacks by a group loyal to ISIS, there are fears that the grief will turn into more violence.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sri Lanka, Notre-Dame, Joe Biden: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: A security team at the site of a mass burial near St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A strategy shift for ISIS.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC

item.title: Venezuelan Migrants Missing After Boat Sinks
item.description: Searchers combed the Caribbean for 25 Venezuelan migrants missing after a boat sank in rough seas on the way to Trinidad.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter 104: Examining Religion and Violence
item.media:description: Nuns praying at the mass funeral at St. Sebastian’s Church, Negombo, Srilanka, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s Australia Letter asks: Is religion making the world more violent? And how can we keep extremism in check?
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Sri Lankan Accused of Leading Attacks Preached Slaughter. Many Dismissed Him.
item.media:description: Zaharan Hashim raged about how Western infidel traditions were poisoning Kattankudy.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The man accused of masterminding the Easter Sunday attacks on churches and hotels never hid his hatred. “We all underestimated him,” a resident of his hometown said.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH

item.title: North Korea Demanded $2 Million Before Releasing Comatose U.S. Student
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier, an American student who was detained in North Korea, died six days after being released.
item.description: The bill for the medical care of Otto F. Warmbier, who was in a coma while being detained, was passed to the Treasury Department, but it is unclear if the Trump administration paid it.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Joe Biden, ISIS, Jazz Fest: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Jessica Griffin/The Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: April 19-25
item.media:description: Security personnel rescue people from a building during an attack on the Afghan communications ministry in central Kabul on April 20, 2019.
item.description: At least 16 pro-government forces and 15 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and FATIMA FAIZI
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Macron, Chastened by Yellow Vest Protests, Says ‘I Can Do Better’
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron promised to lower taxes, stop the closing of rural schools and hospitals, and peg some pensions to inflation.
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, at the first news conference of his presidency, showed the wear of the economic and social protests that have torn France.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Trilobites: An Emperor Penguin Colony in Antarctica Vanishes
item.media:description: Emperor penguin chicks in 2010 at Halley Bay in Antarctica. For three years, beginning in 2016, researchers have found an almost “total breeding failure.”
item.media:credit: Peter Fretwell/British Antarctic Survey, via Associated Press
item.description: A colony in Halley Bay lost more than 10,000 chicks in 2016 and hasn’t recovered. Some adults have relocated.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEINTRAUB

item.title: Erdogan’s Party Is Deeply Divided by Push to Redo Istanbul Election
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, center left, with the leader of the Nationalist Movement Party, Devlet Bahceli, second from right, on Tuesday in Ankara.
item.description: Supporters and opponents alike warn that an annulment and new election has steep risks that could only compound the political fallout for the president.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: ISIS, Joe Biden, Australia’s Feral Cats: Your Friday Briefing
item.media:description: Mourners at the grave in Negombo of a victim of the Easter Sunday bombings in Sri Lanka.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: ISIS shifts its strategy.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN HILTNER and KATIE VAN SYCKLE

item.title: 6 Employees of Turkish Newspaper Return to Jail in Terrorism Case
item.media:description: The Turkish journalists, including the cartoonist Musa Kart, center left, at a news conference this week in Istanbul.
item.description: Journalists and other employees of Cumhuriyet were convicted of aiding terrorism last year in a case seen as having grave implications for press freedom.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Notre-Dame Fire Investigators Focus on Short-Circuit and Cigarettes
item.media:description: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris on Thursday, when police investigators entered for the first time since the structure was stabilized.
item.description: The police searched the cathedral’s vast interior and say they are considering electric bells in and near the spire as a possible cause. Worker negligence is also being examined.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Climate Fwd:: One Thing You Can Do: Know Your Plastics
item.media:description: Henry Fountain on the Nisqually Glacier on Mount Rainier in Washington.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: Also this week, how it feels to stand on a melting glacier.
item.dc:creator: EDUARDO GARCIA and HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Polio Vaccinator Is Shot and Killed in Pakistan
item.media:description: Security officials investigating an attack by gunmen on a polio vaccination team on Thursday that left one woman dead in the town of Chaman, in Pakistan.
item.description: The woman was part of a vaccination campaign. Another worker in her team was injured. A total of three polio workers have been killed this week as unfounded rumors against vaccines spread.
item.dc:creator: HAROON JANJUA

item.title: Weeks After Deadly Storm, Cyclone Kenneth Hits Mozambique
item.media:description: A satellite image released by NASA showing Cyclone Kenneth approaching Mozambique on Thursday.
item.description: Just over a month after Cyclone Idai left more than 1,000 dead in the region, Cyclone Kenneth struck the East African nation of Mozambique, where residents were bracing for dangerous floods.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF

item.title: Olympic Athletes’ Feud Goes Public, With Claims of Hotel Theft and Gym Attack
item.media:description: Mo Farah during the Great North Run last year in Newcastle Upon Tyne, England.
item.description: Two legends of long-distance running, Mo Farah and Haile Gebrselassie, found themselves embroiled in a very public war of words.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SCHAVERIEN
item.category: Yaya Africa Athletics Village (Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, Hotel)

item.title: Sri Lanka Attack Signals ISIS’ Widening Reach
item.media:description: A funeral in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday for victims of the Easter Sunday bombings, an attack that the Islamic State claimed responsibility for.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A month after losing the last of its territory in Iraq and Syria, the Islamic State is believed to have pulled off one of its deadliest attacks. It may be the way of the future.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
